key_points: Donald Trump, a former reality TV star and businessman, was elected president in 2016 without any prior government or military experience.
Trump's presidency was marked by significant polarization, with a focus on political fights and criticism of perceived adversaries.
He was the first president to be impeached twice and refused to attend his successor's inauguration.
Trump's policy achievements included major tax cuts, deregulation, reshaping the federal judiciary, and significant changes in immigration and trade policies.
His tenure accelerated societal shifts and deepened partisan divides in America.
An analysis by Pew Research Center highlights the societal changes during Trump's presidency, focusing on deepening partisan and personal divides.
Republicans and Democrats had vastly different views on Trump, with an 80-point gap in approval ratings.
The divide extended to personal relationships and conversations, with many Americans avoiding politics in discussions.
Polarization in American society increased significantly during Trump's tenure, with widening gaps in core political values and issues.
Republicans and Democrats increasingly disagreed not just over policies but over basic facts, with reciprocal distrust in the media.
